Identify the authentication mechanism used by the application. Most applications use usernames and passwords for authentication. However, there are other options available, such as certificates.

Identify the authentication code. Identify the code that is responsible for authentication both on the iOS device and on the remote server. The authentication itself should be implemented on the server. To protect authentication credentials in transit, both end points need to support SSL.
Review authentication code. Examine authentication code to make sure that it uses SSL to send authentication credentials.

Inspect packet captures. Use a tool such as Wireshark to capture packets sent by the application during authentication. Inspect the captured packets to make sure that authentication credentials are not sent in plain-text.

html:
Applies To

  • iOS applications that authenticate to a remote server.

What to Check For

Verify that authentication credentials sent over the network are encrypted.

Why

Encrypting authentication credentials sent over the network helps prevent various man-in-the-middle attacks, such as spoofing or hijacking.

How to Check

To verify that authentication credentials are encrypted when sent over the network:

  1. Identify the authentication mechanism used by the application. Most applications use usernames and passwords for authentication. However, there are other options available, such as certificates.
  2. Identify the authentication code. Identify the code that is responsible for authentication both on the iOS device and on the remote server. The authentication itself should be implemented on the server. To protect authentication credentials in transit, both end points need to support SSL.
  3. Review authentication code. Examine authentication code to make sure that it uses SSL to send authentication credentials.
  4. Inspect packet captures. Use a tool such as Wireshark to capture packets sent by the application during authentication. Inspect the captured packets to make sure that authentication credentials are not sent in plain-text.

How to Fix

To encrypt authentication credentials sent over the network:

  1. Identify the authentication mechanism used by the application. Most applications use usernames and passwords for authentication. However, there are other options available, such as certificates.
  2. Identify the authentication code. Identify the code that is responsible for authentication both on the iOS device and on the remote server. The authentication itself should be implemented on the server. To protect authentication credentials in transit, both end points need to support SSL.
  3. Encrypt authentication credentials in transit. Add code that uses SSL to protect authentication credentials in transit. The server should be configured to only accept authentication credentials via SSL. The iOS NSURLRequest and NSURLConnection classes support SSL and should be sufficient for many common authentication scenarios.

  • Implement a Secure Password Reset Function
  • Throttle Authentication Attempts
  • Use Server-side Authentication
